articles.headline: Surge of Zika Virus Has Brazilians Re-examining Strict Abortion Laws
articles.snippet: Abortion rights activists are seizing on the crisis to push back against conservative lawmakers who want to toughen already stringent limits.
articles.abstract: Abortion rights activists are seizing on the crisis to push back against conservative lawmakers who want to toughen already stringent limits.
articles.lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — The surging medical reports of babies being born with unusually small heads during the Zika epidemic in Brazil are igniting a fierce debate over the country’s abortion laws, which make the procedure illegal under most circumstances.

articles.headline: Toxic Loans Around the World Weigh on Global Growth
articles.snippet: Bad debts have been a drag on economic activity ever since the financial crisis of 2008, but the threat appears to be rising, and China is the biggest source of worry.
articles.abstract: Bad debts have been a drag on economic activity ever since the financial crisis of 2008, but the threat appears to be rising, and China is the biggest source of worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beneath the surface of the global financial system lurks a multitrillion-dollar problem that could sap the strength of large economies for years to come.

articles.headline: Sumner Redstone Steps Down as CBS Chairman, Replaced by Leslie Moonves
articles.snippet: A lawsuit challenging Mr. Redstone’s mental competence had raised questions among analysts and investors about his suitability for the job.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit challenging Mr. Redstone’s mental competence had raised questions among analysts and investors about his suitability for the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 92-year-old media mogul Sumner M. Redstone has declared repeatedly over the years that he would never retire from his perch at the top of his $39 billion entertainment empire.

articles.headline: Walmart Sues Puerto Rico, Claiming an Unfair and Onerous Tax Burden
articles.snippet: Walmart, which sued the island in December, said a change to the island’s tax law last year was discriminatory and had resulted in an effective income tax of 91.5 percent for the chain.
articles.abstract: Walmart, which sued the island in December, said a change to the island’s tax law last year was discriminatory and had resulted in an effective income tax of 91.5 percent for the chain.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last thing Puerto Rico would seem to need is another fight about money.

articles.headline: Republicans Reach Out to New Hampshire Women With Softer Tone
articles.snippet: New Hampshire women, many of them independents or moderate Republicans, have emerged as perhaps the most critical swing vote in the primary next week.
articles.abstract: New Hampshire women, many of them independents or moderate Republicans, have emerged as perhaps the most critical swing vote in the primary next week.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — The Republican presidential race has seemed at times like a contest of schoolyard insults and chest-thumping machismo. With Donald J. Trump leading the way, the campaign has repeatedly descended into a kind of primal struggle among men, each seeking to outdo his rivals through brutish intimidation.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Playboy Puts On (Some) Clothes for Newly Redesigned Issue
articles.snippet: The magazine still has plenty of semi-nude pictures, which feel more impromptu than posed, as well as long articles.
articles.abstract: The magazine still has plenty of semi-nude pictures, which feel more impromptu than posed, as well as long articles.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is Playboy without naked women? It sounds a little bit like Car and Driver magazine without cars or drivers, and for readers who want only to gawk at the most intimate of female parts, it is just that. For everyone else, the makeover is subtler than you might expect. And frankly, the starkest changes have little to do with flesh.

articles.headline: Obama Is Pressed to Open Military Front Against ISIS in Libya
articles.snippet: The number of Islamic State fighters in Libya has grown to between 5,000 and 6,500, Pentagon officials said, more than double the estimate of last fall.
articles.abstract: The number of Islamic State fighters in Libya has grown to between 5,000 and 6,500, Pentagon officials said, more than double the estimate of last fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is being pressed by some of his national security aides, including his top military advisers, to approve the use of American forces in Libya to open another front against the Islamic State.

articles.headline: Martin Shkreli Invokes the Fifth Amendment During Grilling by Congress
articles.snippet: Lawmakers questioned drug company executives Thursday, focusing on pricing practices, and criticized Martin Shkreli for refusing to answer questions.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers questioned drug company executives Thursday, focusing on pricing practices, and criticized Martin Shkreli for refusing to answer questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli’s grilling by Congress on Thursday proved to be the spectacle that many had long anticipated.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Emmarie Huetteman

articles.headline: Disappointed With Europe, Thousands of Iraqi Migrants Return Home
articles.snippet: Many of the Iraqis who joined Syrians, Africans and Afghans in the great migrant wave to Europe last year with expectations of quick success are now turning around.
articles.abstract: Many of the Iraqis who joined Syrians, Africans and Afghans in the great migrant wave to Europe last year with expectations of quick success are now turning around.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Night after night, Mohammed al-Jabiry tossed and turned in his bed at a refugee center in Finland, comparing life in Europe with life in Baghdad. After many sleepless nights, he decided to come home.
